body: They have seen the twin towers fall, smelled the burned air, maneuvered around police barricades, sensed the intangible but inescapable mood of a city on edge. Now they want out. ''Manhattan, I think, is over for us,'' said Ralph Esposito, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Chase, who has been staying in his family's Southampton summer home with
title: Fight or Flight? Two Primal Urges at War; With Small Children, Prudence Is the Rule

body: Deborah Williamson and Mary Wible left special event and public relations jobs at Condé Nast Publications almost two years ago, using cash investments from friends to start a small business planning parties in Manhattan. It was risky, to say the least. ''There have been lots of scary moments,'' Ms. Wible said. The bet more than paid off. Their
title: Adapting To a World Less Ready For a Party

body: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. EUGENE CLARK From the Terrace In life, Eugene Clark observed the three D's: dance, drama and divas. He started early: Roberta Flack was his music teacher in Washington, D.C., during the 1960's. He could sing like Jennifer Holliday in the musical
title: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICTIMS; Routines And Plans, And Friends And Family

author: Vince Passaro is a novelist living in New York City.
body: We have a tendency to measure the life of New York by the habits and welfare of the upper-middle classes, which is rather like taking all your weather reports from 25,000 feet in the air. The vast majority of New Yorkers make less than $40,000 per year. This is their city too, though that version of New York doesn't have a series yet on HBO.
title: The Way We Live Now: 11-11-01: Sightlines; The View From Out Here

body: To the Editor: The way that your article wove together the strands of Paul Lisson's life, his few but dear friends, his mother's illness and the sad reflections of his estranged father left me speechless. I noticed a woman on the subway reading the article. As she finished, her eyes welled up with tears, as mine had, and she wiped them away
title: What to Tell a Child; Taking Account Of a 'Hidden Life'

body: The primary election scheduled for Sept. 11 but postponed because of the terrorist attack will be held today. Absentee ballots submitted before Sept. 11 count, but votes cast at polling places that day do not. This list summarizes The Times's recommendations in some primary races throughout New York City and Nassau County. All are Democratic
title: Voting Today in New York

author: These profiles were written by Diane Cardwell, Glenn Collins, Winnie Hu, Andrew Jacobs, Dean E. Murphy, Lynda Richardson, Janny Scott, Somini Sengupta and Joyce Wadler.
body: The official number of deaths in the destruction of the World Trade Center stands at 159, and the medical examiner has identified only a few dozen victims. It could be months before many of those killed can be officially confirmed dead. Nearly 5,000 are missing. Here are glimpses of some of those lives. MARY YOLANDA DOWLING The Voice of an Angel
title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MISSING; Snapshots of Their Lives, Told With the Pain of Those Who Loved Them

title: AFTER THE ATTACKS: RELICS; Trade Center's Past In a Sad Paper Trail

body: Merriam-Webster's Online Dictionary defines ''flaneur'' as ''an idle man-about-town.'' But Lawrence Levi had a broader meaning in mind when he created a Web zine that pays homage to the French word. ''As Moli'ere saw it, and writers today like Edmund White,'' Mr. Levi said, ''he is an urban wanderer, a detached observer who immerses himself in the
title: NEW YORK ONLINE; How to Be a Boulevardier

body: One building, one superintendent, is how Nathaniel remembers his job. ''You'd wake up in the morning and take care of your building like it was your own,'' said Nathaniel, who asked that his last name not be used. But for many city supers, those days are becoming rare. Last year, Nathaniel, 43, lost his job and apartment in Carroll Gardens,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; A Part-Time Super? Does This Lower the Christmas Tip?

The candidates' résumés cover the spectrum of local politics in what is commonly known as brownstone Brooklyn, but their names
title: Boasts in 6-Way Race: Experience and Endorsements

Here are our recommendations in seven important Democratic races in the Sept. 11 primary. 33rd District (Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg, Greenpoint): David
title: Council Endorsements: Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: In ''Destroy a Freeway, Save a City'' (Op-Ed, Aug. 23), Charles Lockwood says ''New York was fortunate to have been spared Robert Moses' proposed Lower Manhattan Expressway,'' but other parts of New York City were not so fortunate. Moses' Brooklyn-Queens Expressway ripped apart neighborhoods in Brooklyn like Carroll Gardens, Red Hook
title: Brooklyn Waterfront

body: COOKIES AND COUSCOUS (212) 477-6562; 230 Thompson Street (West Third Street); $; $25 and Under: 7/28/99. ''Middle Eastern'' covers a broad range of cuisines, from Morocco to Turkey to Iran to Egypt. This small bright Moroccan restaurant has a lot more going for it than the peculiar name suggests. The short menu emphasizes seasonal ingredients.
title: GOOD EATING; Middle East Variations

body: HERE is my idea of a perfect summer meal: a delectable salad, a light sandwich, a glass or two of wine, and maybe a sweet. It's a formula to beat the heat, and it makes me want to keep returning to Panino'teca 275, an Italian sandwich and wine bar that opened early this year on the ever-evolving strip of restaurants on Smith Street in Brooklyn. In
title: $25 AND UNDER; Tapas, Italian Style, Perfectly Cool in the Heat

body: AN 800-square-foot apartment that sits practically on top of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and around the corner from an entrance to the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel may not be everyone's idea of an urban oasis. But for Avi Adler and David Stark, a renovated one-bedroom home on the roof of a nondescript 1940's Brooklyn building is paradise found. Mr.
title: HOUSE PROUD; A Sleek Aerie Atop the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel

body: THE subtle blue storefront of Bistro St. Mark's sits on a nondescript block on the fringe of Park Slope. It blends so inconspicuously with the surroundings that on my first visit I walked by twice before realizing, with a double take, that I was right at the door. A look at the menu provokes a double take, too, because this is no simple bistro
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Movable Chef Stirs Things Up in Park Slope

body: When the long-troubled John Jay High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, closed its doors for good a week ago today, the goodbyes were tinged with a mix of emotions. Some students and teachers at the academically struggling school said they believed that they were being forced out by middle-class neighborhood parents looking for a new school for their
title: Reinventing John Jay High Amid Charges of Exclusion

body: IF Yamani Sekhri, who received her M.B.A. from Indiana University in May, had been searching for an apartment in Manhattan a year ago, Michael Shapot would have had one listing, maybe two, to show her on any given day. But this year is different. Ms. Sekhri, who began as an investment banking associate with UBS Warburg in May, phoned Mr. Shapot, an
title: For Class of 2001, a Less Frenetic Market

body: The Swedish furniture retailer Ikea, whose stores are so large that they provide customers with maps, has outlets in Russia and China, in Slovakia and Saudi Arabia. But it does not have a store in New York City, and for now, it will not. Ikea's plan to buy a nine-acre site near the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn and build a 300,000-square-foot store
title: Ikea Scrapping Plans for Store Amid Resistance by Neighbors

body: Time seems to have forgotten Columbia Street, a tattered roadway at the western edge of Cobble Hill where ghostly trolley tracks and Belgian blocks that once paved the road can still be found poking through the worn asphalt. But the city's Department of Transportation has a plan that officials say will invigorate the part of the street that runs
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL/CARROLL GARDENS; A Wider Street Is (a) Safer (b) More Congested

body: Some Old Standards Dishes that might be clichés suit the setting at 92, Ken Aretsky's new place at 45 East 92nd Street. The restaurant is slightly retro-looking, with booths and tables in a burgundy color scheme. The full menu, available starting on Friday, includes grilled chicken Caesar salad, meatloaf, soft-shell crabs, and iceberg lettuce and
title: OFF THE MENU

body: A FAMILIAR green image of a mermaid stands on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, near the corner of Coffey Street. ''Coming Soon,'' the sign says, ''Starbucks Coffey.'' Both a play on words and a joking reference to the neighborhood's nascent gentrification, the sign does not seem an accurate prediction -- at least not yet. With a long history
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Hook; Isolated Brooklyn Area Starts to Awaken

body: Like most people who spend their days on the banks of the Gowanus Canal, a two-mile stretch of water that starts at the mouth of New York Harbor and dead-ends in South Brooklyn, Dan Kinney used to run for cover when barges came through, kicking up the putrid refuse that had settled on the bottom. ''Run for the nearest building and close the door!''
title: Once a Mess, Canal Aspires To Beauty Now

body: The New York City Industrial Development Agency will help three manufacturing enterprises expand their operations in three boroughs. All the companies plan to add employees. The agency has arranged for $1.5 million in bond financing and $551,000 in real estate and sales tax benefits for Rome Knitting Mills/Orbit Industries for the purchase and
title: Metro Business Briefing | Aid For Expanding Companies

body: A CLASSIFIED ad in The Daily News last September set in motion the events that are leading Linda Hamlin to make the first housing change of her life. For all her 42 years Ms. Hamlin has lived in a small three-bedroom one-bath apartment in Gowanus Houses on Baltic Street in South Brooklyn. At one time seven family members lived there, but currently
title: New Roles for Nonprofit Housing Groups

body: ONE afternoon last summer I was sauntering home with a bag of vegetables when I saw something on my Brooklyn street corner that stopped me in my tracks: a red double-decker sightseeing bus and a throng of sunburned, backpack-toting tourists, chattering excitedly in some Scandinavian language. Cameras flashed and whirred. What was this all about?
title: FRUGAL TRAVELER; Playing Tourist at Home in Brooklyn

body: A federal grand jury in Manhattan is investigating whether a city police detective tampered with evidence to help cover up his cousin's role in a 1998 mob killing on the Brooklyn waterfront, officials said. The F.B.I. and federal prosecutors are investigating whether the detective, Michael Silvestri, 44, who was assigned to the 76th Precinct in
title: Officer Suspected of Cover-Up in Killing

body: THE name conjures up images of peaceful 19th-century residential streets, which in many ways are still present. But the only cobblestones near the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn -- one of the oldest residential neighborhoods in the borough -- can be found in a largely industrial area just west of the neighborhood on a street named Tiffany Place.
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cobble Hill; A Landmark Area With a Family Bent

body: Patriotic Chic Q. Any particular reason that the managers at Lord & Taylor always play ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' over the public address system when the store opens? A. title: F.Y.I.

body: Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer that was forced last month to scrap its plans for a superstore in Westchester, is considering putting a store on a nine-acre site on the banks of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, two people involved in the deal said yesterday. The planned store, which would be Ikea's first in New York City, would be built along
title: Ikea Is Said To Consider Gowanus Site For New Store

body: Lately, as Carroll Gardens has complained about noise and vibrations from construction crews, Brooklyn Heights residents have been fretting about why their area is so quiet. Work on major renovations of the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, which began in November, stopped abruptly several weeks ago, causing concern that the project may not meet its June
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The Sounds of Silence Give Promenade Neighbors Pause

author: Sarah Jean Shey is working on a book about the flight from the farm to the city. She lives in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn.
body: FOR a second, I thought I was in my native Iowa at a livestock auction and not Morningside Heights, where I was living as a graduate student. This was New York, I reminded myself, which had been my home for several months. I put down my newspaper to concentrate on the neighborhood noises: an answering machine, a honk, a pig squeal. I flung open the
title: FIRST PERSON; The Neighbor Was a Real Pig

body: Dozens of gay couples in New York will celebrate their first Valentine's Day on Wednesday as legal spouses, thanks to a new Vermont law that allows same-sex couples to enter into civil unions. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Gay Couples Head North To Make Their Unions Official

body: THERE'S a power struggle under way in many households between parents and nannies, and the nannies seem to be gaining the upper hand. Just check out the chat rooms proliferating on the Internet, where nannies
title: Nannies Get Tough, Parents Tremble
